newsitem.title: USA: Thermo Cardiosystems buys Thermo Electron unit. [CORRECTED 15:48 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Thermo Cardiosystems buys Thermo Electron unit. [CORRECTED 15:48 GMT]

text.p: (Corrects headline to make clear that a Thermo Electron unit was bought, and not the parent company.)

Thermo Cardiosystems Inc said on Friday that it had acquired International Technidyne Corp, a subsidiary of Thermo Electron Corp, in exchange for 3,355,705 shares of Thermo Cardiosystems common stock.

The transaction was accounted for in a manner similar to a pooling of interests, the company said in a statement. The issuance of the new shares of Thermo Cardiosystems common stock is subject to ratification by Thermo Cardiosystems' shareholders, it added.
Based in Edison, New Jersey, International Technidyne manufactures near-patient, whole-blood coagulation-testing equipment, as well as skin-incision devices.
In 1996, International Technidyne had revenues of $34 million, with net income of $4.7 million, Thermo Cardiosystems said.
"This acquisition broadens our product base and provides another avenue for growth," said Thermo Cardiosystems chief executive Victor Poirier.
Thermo Cardiosystems is a researcher and manufacturer of implantable left ventricular-assist systems (LVAS).
